awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  WoU-MMA: Askaryan Radio Array:  The World's Forefront Neutrino Astrophysics Program from 100 PeV
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will push the frontier of ultra-high-energy (UHE) neutrino astrophysics above 100 peta-electron-volts (PeV) with the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA) testbed at the South Pole Station, whose dataset is now large enough to enable either a discovery of the highest energy neutrinos ever detected or setting the world’s best constraints in this crucial energy regime.  The study will continue operation of this testbed experiment, doubling the size of the dataset in the next three years, streamline neutrino searches in the growing ARA dataset, calibrate simulations of neutrino detectors using newly-detected cosmic ray air showers, and test next-generation data acquisition electronics in the South Pole environment.  ARA serves as a platform for recruitment of young scientists into STEM fields, and the development of junior scientists to work on the next generation of UHE neutrino detectors.  This group engages secondary-school, undergraduate and graduate students in innovative neutrino research, and will develop a new module for the Masterclass for high school students on big data strategies to search for rare events in large datasets, using data from ARA and from the IceCube Neutrino Observatory.

The radio technique used by ARA allows astrophysics to extend to these UHE neutrinos.  ARA is laying the groundwork for the radio component of the next generation of neutrino observatories.  A neutrino observation from ARA will constrain the properties of any global population of sources of the highest energy cosmic rays, complementing cosmic ray experiments that sample only local sources at the highest energies.  Any event detected would be the highest energy neutrino ever observed, cosmic or terrestrial, and be the first-ever detection of a neutrino via radio frequency emission.  This would be a major event in the pursuit of UHE neutrinos, and would provide crucial information for the technical design of future facilities.  This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last three decades, and aided by significant advances in digital technology, the detection of either coherent radio-frequency (RF) Cherenkov radiation, or RF echoes from cascades in dense media, has emerged as the most cost-effective approach to measure Ultra-High Energy Neutrinos (UHEN). Following initial simulations in the early 90's (ZHS/FMR), meter-scale antennas deployed in RF-transparent ice is the strategy which has been employed by the RICE (1996-2012), ARA (2011-), RET (2021-) and RNO-G (2018-) experiments, and also contemplated for the radio component of the future IceCube-Gen2 experiment. Below we detail progress specific to the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA) experiment, as led by the three graduate students most seminally involved.

1. Graduate student Mohammad Ful Hossain Seikh is conducting the neutrino search, based on analysis of ARA station 01 (A1) data, accumulated from 2012-present. Over the last year, Mohammad has largely finalized the analysis algorithms and performed necessary calibration, including 1) calibration of the amplitude conversion in the digitizer (ADC counts->Voltage), 2) calibration of the time base of the digitizer (sample interval->nanoseconds), 3) definition of the algorithms used to suppress continuous wave (CW) contamination in the ARA data sample, and 4) definition of the algorithms used to define the run-dependent amplifier gain, over the 12-year period of data-taking. Mohammad has also performed detailed characterization, in the KU anechoic chamber, of the antennas to be used (both VPol and HPol) in the neutrino search. Overall, he is well-poised to begin analysis of the 10% `unblinded' sample used to establish final signal-definition cuts.

2. Graduate student Shoukat Ali, following earlier work of former graduate student Uzair Latif, is investigating ultra-high energy cosmic ray (UHECR) signatures in the ARA data sample, as well as possible UHECR backgrounds to neutrino searches. Of particular interest is an event registered in ARA station A2, identified in the previous neutrino search analysis, which suggested two radio signals, separated by approximately 100 nanoseconds in time. Such an event topology may be consistent with the double pulse arising from the geomagnetic emissions from an air shower core developing in the Earth's atmosphere, followed by the Askaryan radio emissions resulting when the core impacts the Earth's surface. This work has formed the basis of Shoukat's Master's thesis; with the development of the FAIRIES simulation framework (based on earlier work by Uzair), Shoukat is now in the process of performing Monte Carlo simulations to establish the consistency (or inconsistency) of the particular A2 event with the double pulse origin hypothesized above.

3. Graduate student Kenny Couberly has been studying the refractive index profile, at radio-frequencies, through the shallowest 120 meters of Antarctic (and also Greenlandic) ice. As the ice accumulates with time, increasing overburden pressure compactifies snow/ice, eventually reaching the asymptotic maximum density at approximately 150-200 meters. The variable density profile for shallower depths results in a variable refractive index profile, which produces interesting phenomenology (curved trajectories) in signal ray tracing. Although most radio experiments have favored a smoothly varying exponential profile, consistent with a self-gravitating atmospheric scale height model, Kenny has shown that a three-phase model, with phase transitions at approximately 20 and 80 meter depth, actually provides a better fit to the existing calibration data. This work has been written up, posted on arxiv.org and is currently in the review stage at Physical Review D.

In addition to this, graduate student Curtis McLennan has been working towards quantifying the rate at which dry boreholes close, in the absence of drilling fluid, based on the constancy of calibration pulser signals, over time, coupled with simulations. That work has shown initial progress and may also form the basis of a future publication.
